Node.Argument1: number (default: no limits) If min_distance_to_players exceeds max_distance_to_players, no objects are placed
Node.Description: Maximum distance (in tiles) from the origin of player lands, that the object can be placed.
Node.AdditionalInfo1: It is not necessary to specify both min_distance_to_players and max_distance_to_players.
Node.AdditionalInfo2: Distance is a square, not a circle.
Node.AdditionalInfo3: If the objects are grouped, distance refers to the center of the group, not the individual group members.
Node.AdditionalInfo4: When used with place_on_specific_land_id, distances refer to that specific land.
Node.AdditionalInfo5: When used without set_place_for_every_player or place_on_specific_land_id, maximum distance has no effect.
Node.Bug1: If distances are very constrained (ie. min=max), objects are noticeably biased towards being placed in the west (ie. starting villagers).

Example1.Description: Place the starting scout at a distance of 7-9 tiles.

Node.Example1: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> create_object SCOUT { set_place_for_every_player min_distance_to_players 7 max_distance_to_players 9 }

Node.Name: max_distance_to_other_zones
Node.Argument1: number (default: 0)
Node.Description: Minimum (NOT maximum), distance in tiles that objects will stay away from terrains that they are restricted from being placed on.
Node.AdditionalInfo1: Useful for keeping resources away from coastlines, or deep fish away from beaches.
Node.AdditionalInfo2: If the objects are grouped, distance refers to the center of the group, not the individual members.
Node.AdditionalInfo3: Does not apply to road terrains, even though resources cannot be placed on them.
Node.AdditionalInfo4: Useless for objects without any terrain restrictions.

Example1.Description: Place a central lake and then fill the map with gold that avoids being close to water.

Node.Example1: <LAND_GENERATION> create_land { terrain_type WATER number_of_tiles 500 land_position 50 50 } <OBJECTS_GENERATION> create_object GOLD { number_of_groups 9000 set_gaia_object_only max_distance_to_other_zones 5 }

Node.Name: min_distance_group_placement
Node.Argument1: number (default: 0)
Node.Description: Minimum distance in tiles that individual objects of the same create_object command, and ALL future objects, must stay away from each object.
Node.AdditionalInfo1: Best used with small values, to keep different resources from being directly next to each other.
Node.AdditionalInfo2: To scatter objects from the same command far away from each other, use temp_min_distance_group_placement
If the objects are grouped, distance applies to whole groups, and refers to the center.

Example1.Description: Give each player two sets of forages and make them avoid each other by 4 tiles, and keep all future objects 4 tiles away.

Node.Example1: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> create_object FORAGE { number_of_objects 7 number_of_groups 2 set_tight_grouping set_place_for_every_player set_gaia_object_only min_distance_to_players 8 max_distance_to_players 10 min_distance_group_placement 4 }

Node.Name: temp_min_distance_group_placement
Node.Argument1: number (default: 0)
Node.Description: Like min_distance_group_placement, but only applies to the current create_object command - future objects are unaffected.
Node.AdditionalInfo1: Useful for scattering objects, for example neutral resources and relics.
Node.AdditionalInfo2: Can be used together with min_distance_group_placement
Node.AdditionalInfo3: If the objects are grouped, distance applies to whole groups, and refers to the center.

Example1.Description: Scatter neutral gold evenly across the map.

Node.Example1: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> create_object GOLD { number_of_groups 9320 number_of_objects 4 set_gaia_object_only set_tight_grouping min_distance_group_placement 4 temp_min_distance_group_placement 46 }

Node.Name: find_closest
Node.Description: Place the object on the closest free tile to the center of the land, taking into consideration all other constraints (Requires: set_place_for_every_player or place_on_specific_land_id)
Node.AdditionalInfo1: max_distance_to_players is unnecessary when using find_closest.
Node.AdditionalInfo2: IMPORTANT: find_closest uses the circular distance, while all other distance constraints (ie. min_distance_to_players) use a square distance. As a result, using both find_closest and min_distance_to_players (without further constraints) will often place objects at 90° to each other because the corners of the square are further from the center than the edges.

Example1.Description: Give each player a fishing ship on the closest free (water) tile.

Node.Example1: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> create_object FISHING_SHIP { set_place_for_every_player find_closest }

Node.Name: force_placement
Node.Description: Allows multiple objects to be placed on the same tile at once, if necessary. Normally, objects are placed one per tile, and if the tiles run out, no more objects are placed. With force_placement active, when tiles run out, the remaining objects are placed on the corners of tiles, and then on top of each other.
Node.AdditionalInfo1: Only works for objects that can overlap on the same tile (ie. units, but not buildings)
Node.AdditionalInfo2: Disabled when using set_loose_grouping
Node.Bug1: When objects are constrained, often generates an excess of the number of objects specified. This renders the main purpose of the attribute useless.

Example1.Description: Place 50 (+ a few buggy extra) sheep in the 1-tile surrounding a starting outpost.

Node.Example1: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> create_object OUTPOST { set_place_for_every_player max_distance_to_players 0 } create_object SHEEP { number_of_objects 50 set_place_for_every_player max_distance_to_players 1 force_placement }

Node.Name: actor_area
Node.Argument1: number (default: 0 - no actor area)
Node.Description: Specifies a numerical identifier which can be referred to in future objects with avoid_actor_area or actor_area_to_place_in

Example1.Description: Spawn a wolf next to each relic.

Node.Example1: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> create_object RELIC { number_of_objects 5 set_gaia_object_only temp_min_distance_group_placement 35 actor_area 1234 } create_object WOLF { number_of_objects 9320 set_gaia_object_only actor_area_to_place_in 1234 temp_min_distance_group_placement 25 }

Node.Name: actor_area_radius
Node.Argument1: number (default: 1 = 3x3 area)
Node.Description: Used with actor_area to specify how large it should be.

Example1.Description: Give each player a mill with 7 deer in a 7-tile radius.

Node.Example1: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> create_object MILL { set_place_for_every_player min_distance_to_players 16 max_distance_to_players 20 actor_area 61 actor_area_radius 7 } create_object DEER { number_of_objects 7 set_place_for_every_player set_gaia_object_only actor_area_to_place_in 61 }

Node.Name: actor_area_to_place_in
Node.Argument1: number
Node.Description: Place the object only within the radius of the specified actor_area
Node.AdditionalInfo1: Overrides max_distance_to_players (BUG?)

Example1.Description: Place a lumber camp on the nearest forest and place villagers there too.

Node.Example1: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> create_object LUMBER_CAMP { set_place_for_every_player max_distance_to_players 67 place_on_forest_zone find_closest actor_area 8 actor_area_radius 4 } create_object VILLAGER { set_place_for_every_player number_of_objects 4 actor_area_to_place_in 8 place_on_forest_zone find_closest }

Node.Name: avoid_actor_area
Node.Argument1: argument_1_description
Node.Description: The object will avoid the specified actor_area
Node.AdditionalInfo1: The same object can avoid multiple actor areas.

Example1.Description: Place a barracks for empire wars and have it avoid various other objects that you already placed.

Node.Example1: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> create_object BARRACKS { set_place_for_every_player min_distance_to_players 7 max_distance_to_players 9 avoid_actor_area 94 avoid_actor_area 40 avoid_actor_area 8 avoid_actor_area 9 avoid_actor_area 99 avoid_actor_area 171 actor_area 51 actor_area_radius 5 }

Node.Name: avoid_all_actor_areas
Node.Description: The object will avoid being placed within ANY existing actor_area

Example1.Description: Place wolves that avoid all actor areas.

Node.Example1: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> create_object TOWN_CENTER { set_place_for_every_player max_distance_to_players 0 actor_area 100 actor_area_radius 60 } create_object WOLF { number_of_objects 9320 temp_min_distance_group_placement 52 avoid_actor_area 100 }

Node.Name: Comment
Node.Argument1: Anything !
Node.Description: A comment is a piece of text that is ignored by the parser, but provides helpful information to someone looking at the code, such as yourself.
Node.AdditionalInfo1: Comments can be nested. If you have a comment within a comment, the "sub comment" will not prematurely terminate the main comment, even if syntax highlighters indicate elsewise.
Node.AdditionalInfo2: Make sure to always include a separator between the comment character and the comment text. This is a common mistake, and many syntax highlighters will not properly recognize broken comments.
Node.AdditionalInfo3: If you are using RMSAssistant, comment are formatted automaticaly, you just have to provide their content.
Node.Bug1: (pre-DE): Comments within dead branches (Conditionals and Random Code) are NOT ignored. For more information, see the external article: Parser Pitfalls

Example1.Description: Working comments

Node.Example1: /* this is a comment */ /* this is a multi-line comment */ /* /* this is a nested */ comment */
Node.Example2: // this is NOT a comment #this is NOT a comment /*this is NOT a comment*/ /*** this is NOT a comment ***/ /* this comment never ends /* this comment never ends*/ /* this comment never ends */*

Node.Name: Constant
Node.Argument1: text + AoC/UP - max length is 99 characters + ANY characters are valid; convention is to use uppercase letters and underscores
Node.Argument2: number (see: Constant Reference in Global documentation)
Node.Description: Assign a label of your choice to a numeric ID, to be able to use the terrain/object associated with that ID.
Node.AdditionalInfo1: This is required to use anything that is not predefined.
Node.AdditionalInfo2: Items can have multiple constants assigned to them.
Node.AdditionalInfo3: You cannot re-define a predefined name to a different ID.
Node.AdditionalInfo4: You cannot use #const as a way to define variable numbers. This will NOT work: #const NUM 10 ==> number_of_objects NUM
Node.AdditionalInfo5: Constants are interpreted in context (ie. after create_object the game will interpret it as an object, while after create_terrain the game will interpret it as a terrain)
Node.AdditionalInfo6: WARNING: Constants without a proper context are interpreted as syntax. For more information, see the external article: Parser Pitfalls

Example1.Description: Define mossy road so you can use it later.

Node.Example1: #const ROAD_FUNGUS 39

Example2.Description: Define and use variable constants depending on the season.

Node.Example2: start_random percent_chance 30 #define WINTER percent_chance 30 #define AUTUMN end_random if WINTER #const LAND_A 32 /* snow */ #const BERRY_TYPE 59 /* berry bush */ elseif AUTUMN #const LAND_A 5 /* leaves */ #const BERRY_TYPE 59 /* berry bush */ else #const LAND_A 3 /* dirt 3 */ #const BERRY_TYPE 1059 /* orange bush */ endif <OBJECTS_GENERATION> create_object BERRY_TYPE { number_of_objects 5 set_place_for_every_player set_gaia_object_only find_closest terrain_to_place_on LAND_A }

Node.Name: Define
Node.Argument1: text + AoC/UP - max length is 99 characters + ANY characters are valid; convention is to use uppercase letters and underscores
Node.Description: Define your own condition labels, to refer to at a later point.
Node.AdditionalInfo1: Do not use any predefined constants.

Example1.Description: Set up seasonal variations for the base terrain.

Node.Example1: start_random percent_chance 20 #define WINTER percent_chance 20 #define AUTUMN end_random <LAND_GENERATION> if WINTER base_terrain SNOW elseif AUTUMN base_terrain LEAVES else base_terrain DIRT3 endif

Node.Name: start_random
Node.Description: Can be used just about anywhere to add an element of randomness to your script.
Node.AdditionalInfo1: Add percent_chance commands to define branches with different odds to be picked during generation.
Node.AdditionalInfo2: If you are using RMSAssistant, all the syntax of this block will be automaticaly generated, incuding the end_random statement

Example1.Description: Place 5 or 6 or 7 gold mines with 6 being the most likely.

Node.Example1: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> create_object GOLD { start_random percent_chance 30 number_of_objects 5 percent_chance 50 number_of_objects 6 percent_chance 20 number_of_objects 7 end_random }

Example2.Description: Have a 10% chance of placing a gold mines (and a 90% of not doing so)

Node.Example2: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> start_random percent_chance 10 create_object GOLD { number_of_objects 5 } end_random

Node.Name: percent_chance
Node.Argument1: number (0-100)
Node.Description: Specify a piece of code that has a defined chance of being chosen.
Node.AdditionalInfo1: If the total percentages add up to less than 100%, there is a chance that none of them get chosen
Node.AdditionalInfo2: If the total exceeds 100%, only the first 100% will have a chance of occurring.
Node.AdditionalInfo3: Random constructs can encompass individual arguments, or even whole blocks of code.
Node.AdditionalInfo4: They cannot be nested. To achieve a non-integer chance, use a first random block to define (using #define) which additional random block to run.
Node.Bug1: (AoC/HD/UP): Comments in dead branches are not ignored. Do not include any random syntax (ie. end_random) in such comments. For more information, see the external article: Parser Pitfalls

Example1.Description: Place 5 or 6 or 7 gold mines with 6 being the most likely.

Node.Example1: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> create_object GOLD { start_random percent_chance 30 number_of_objects 5 percent_chance 50 number_of_objects 6 percent_chance 20 number_of_objects 7 end_random }

Example2.Description: Have a 10% chance of placing a gold mines (and a 90% of not doing so)

Node.Example2: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> start_random percent_chance 10 create_object GOLD { number_of_objects 5 } end_random

Node.Name: Condition
Node.Description: Conditionals are pieces of code that will be executed based on whether a specified condition is fulfilled.
Node.AdditionalInfo1: Can be used within commands or around whole blocks of code.
Node.AdditionalInfo2: Conditionals can be nested.
Node.AdditionalInfo3: If you are using RMSAssistant, all the syntax of this block will be automaticaly generated, including the endif statement, you just have to add conditions

Example1.Description: Manually scale relic count to map size.

Node.Example1: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> create_object RELIC { min_distance_to_players 25 if TINY_MAP number_of_objects 5 temp_min_distance_group_placement 35 elseif SMALL_MAP number_of_objects 5 temp_min_distance_group_placement 38 elseif MEDIUM_MAP number_of_objects 5 temp_min_distance_group_placement 38 elseif LARGE_MAP number_of_objects 7 temp_min_distance_group_placement 48 elseif HUGE_MAP number_of_objects 8 temp_min_distance_group_placement 52 else number_of_objects 999 temp_min_distance_group_placement 52 endif }

Example2.Description: Replace the scout with a king when playing regicide.

Node.Example2: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> if REGICIDE create_object KING else create_object SCOUT endif { set_place_for_every_player min_distance_to_players 7 max_distance_to_players 9 }

Example3.Description: Set up a NOT conditional - place a cow when 'infinite resources' is not true.

Node.Example3: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> if INFINITE_RESOURCES else create_object DLC_COW { set_place_for_every_player find_closest } endif

Node.Name: if
Node.Argument1: either a predefined condition or a custom condition
Node.Description: required once (and once only) in any conditional block. It will execute the code if the condition is true, and will stop checking further conditions.
Node.Bug1: (AoC/HD): Comments in dead branches are not ignored. Do not include any conditional syntax in such comments. Be especially careful with "if" since it is easy to inadvertently type it in a comment! For more information, see the external article: Parser Pitfalls

Example1.Description: Manually scale relic count to map size.

Node.Example1: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> create_object RELIC { min_distance_to_players 25 if TINY_MAP number_of_objects 5 temp_min_distance_group_placement 35 elseif SMALL_MAP number_of_objects 5 temp_min_distance_group_placement 38 elseif MEDIUM_MAP number_of_objects 5 temp_min_distance_group_placement 38 elseif LARGE_MAP number_of_objects 7 temp_min_distance_group_placement 48 elseif HUGE_MAP number_of_objects 8 temp_min_distance_group_placement 52 else number_of_objects 999 temp_min_distance_group_placement 52 endif }

Node.Example3: <OBJECTS_GENERATION> if INFINITE_RESOURCES else create_object DLC_COW { set_place_for_every_player find_closest } endif

Node.Name: elseif
Node.Argument1: either a predefined condition or a custom condition
Node.Description: is optional (and can be specified multiple times). It will be evaluated if the previous condition(s) were not true. If true, no further conditions are checked.
Node.Bug1: (AoC/HD): Comments in dead branches are not ignored. Do not include any conditional syntax in such comments. Be especially careful with "if" since it is easy to inadvertently type it in a comment! For more information, see the external article: Parser Pitfalls

Node.Name: else
Node.Description: is optional and will be executed if all other conditions fail.
Node.Bug1: (AoC/HD): Comments in dead branches are not ignored. Do not include any conditional syntax in such comments. Be especially careful with "if" since it is easy to inadvertently type it in a comment! For more information, see the external article: Parser Pitfalls
